fr:title.text: chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on an algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'(\sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon {\tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d(\sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{\rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.
We have a chain reduction C_* (X \times Y) \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow C_* (X) \otimes C_* (Y).

For every product of simplices \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q, we put on the discrete vector field on \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q. This DVF is admissible because the time a path stays in \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q is bounded by a function of p and q. Then it is sent to a boundary cell.

Using Construction , we get the required chain reduction. This is identical to the Eilenberg–Zilber reduction in literature, but the proof requires some combinatorics, and can be seen in Section 5.13 of Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. However, this formulation gives a much better computational performance.

We construct a discrete vector field on the reduced ACC of \Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q whose critical cells are given by its boundary and one additional cell (0,0) < (1,0) < \cdots < (p,0) < (p,1) < \cdots < (p,q), in the representation scheme of Theorem . In particular, this gives rise to a chain reduction C_*(\Delta ^p \times \Delta ^q) \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow C_*(\Delta ^p) \otimes C_*(\Delta ^q).

Regarding the geometric simplices as paths in a p \times q grid as specified in Theorem , we assign a (p+q)-simplex as a target cell if it contains a shape \Rsh . (The shape must go exactly one step up and one step to the right, since it is not possible otherwise in a geometric (p+q)-simplex.) To get its source cell, replace the last occurrence of this shape with \nearrow .

fr:title.text: chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field reduces an ACC (C_k, d) to a smaller one, which can be explicitly described. Its cells are the critical cells in C_k. For the faces of a cell \sigma , we start with the faces d(\sigma ) in the original ACC. Then we move every non-critical cell down along the discrete field lines, up to some sign flips, until we get to a critical cell.

Note that the field lines alternate between n- and (n+1)-dimensional cells, and we count the movement n – (n+1) – n as a single step. Also, discrete field lines can branch and merge, and the cells need to duplicate and move down every branch.

fr:title.text: reduction from K(\mathbb {Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: reduction from K(\mathbb {Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a chain reduction from the bar construction \bar {W}(G) of a group regarded as its reduced algebraic cellular complex, to the circle \mathbb {S}^1.

By construction, the geometric simplices of K(\mathbb {Z}, 1) are lists [a_1 \mid a_2 \mid \cdots \mid a_n] of non-zero integers. We construct an admissible discrete vector field and use the reduction it generates. We assign a cell [a_1 \mid \cdots ] as a source if a_1 \ne 1. If a_1 \le 0, then we assign its target cell to be [1 \mid a_1 \mid \cdots ]; otherwise we assign [1 \mid a_1 - 1 \mid \cdots ]. Hence, the critical cells are [] and [1].

fr:title.text: reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We construct a chain reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex in Definition , by constructing a discrete vector field and using Construction .

We consider placing vectors on degenerate simplicies, so that all degenerate simplices are sources or targets. For each non-trivial degeneracy symbol, if the first degeneration has even multiplicity, we assign it to be a source, with the corresponding target to have one more multiplicity at the place, and vice versa. For example, the degeneracy symbol [6] \twoheadrightarrow [4] given by the table of values (0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) is a source, whose target is (0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) : [7] \twoheadrightarrow [4].

To verify this indeed gives a discrete vector field, we need to show that the source is a regular face of the target. This is true since an odd consective sum of (-1)^{i} gives \pm 1. Furthermore, we need to show the admissibility of the vector field. I claim that length of the field lines originating from one cell is bounded by two times the geometric dimension (i.e. the dimension of the associated geometric simplex). On one hand, the geometric dimensions of the target and the source are the same. On the other hand, moving from the target to the next source cell requires us to pick a regular face that does not point back to the target. This is equivalent to picking a place in the degeneracy symbol with no multiplicity. Hence the geometric dimension will decrease by one.

Given a discrete vector field, if is admissible if the lengths of the field lines starting from a cell are bounded. In other words, we can assign a natural number to every cell such that the field lines starting from this cell have length bounded by the number. The number can be different for each cell, and can be unbounded overall.

Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

html:ul.html:li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The following data are equivalent.

html:ul.html:li: A splitting C \cong D \oplus E, where E is a split exact.
A chain homotopy h : C \to C satisfying h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0 and h \mathbin {\circ } d_C \mathbin {\circ } h = h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Substituting the requirement that h is a homotopy \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } r_k + r_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k = \textrm {id}, where d is the boundary operator on E_\bullet . In other words, r is a null-homotopy of E_\bullet , rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus E, we can reconstruct f and g as the projection and inclusion maps, with h obtained out of r in the manner depicted above.

On the other hand, given only the homotopy operator, we expect to have d \mathbin {\circ } h + h \mathbin {\circ } d = \textrm {id} - g \mathbin {\circ } f. And since g \mathbin {\circ } f should be the projector of C onto the subspace D, \textrm {id} - g \mathbin {\circ } f should be the projector onto E. We are thus led to proving p = d \mathbin {\circ } h + h \mathbin {\circ } d is indeed a projector. \begin {aligned} p_k \mathbin {\circ } p_k &= (d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k) \mathbin {\circ } (d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } \overbrace {h_k \mathbin {\circ } d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } \overbrace {h_k \mathbin {\circ } h_{k-1}}^{0} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \\ &\qquad + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } \underbrace {d_k \mathbin {\circ } d_{k+1}}_{0} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \mathbin {\circ } h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \mathbin {\circ } d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \mathbin {\circ } h_k + h_{k-1} \mathbin {\circ } d_k = p_k. \end {aligned} Therefore we conclude that p_k splits C_k \cong D_k \oplus E_k. More over, p \mathbin {\circ } d = d \mathbin {\circ } h \mathbin {\circ } d = d \mathbin {\circ } p, meaning p is a chain map, and therefore the splitting is compatible with the boundary operator. Since h \mathbin {\circ } p = p \mathbin {\circ } h = h \mathbin {\circ } d \mathbin {\circ } h = h, the homotopy is also compatible with the splitting, so we can restrict it onto E_k to get a homotopy from \textrm {id}_E to 0.

Finally, restricting h onto D_k we see that it must be zero, since h(\textrm {id} - p) = h - h \mathbin {\circ } d \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. This means that all the information of h can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

fr:title.text: perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D and a perturbation \delta _C for C, we assume that h_{\rho } \mathbin {\circ } \delta _C is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; (h_{\rho }\delta _C)^n (c) = 0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D', where C' is C perturbed by \delta _C.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to Construction , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in Theorem , i.e. a homotopy operator on C such that h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0 and h \mathbin {\circ } d_C \mathbin {\circ } h = h.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^\infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \mathbin {\circ } h' = 0 from h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \mathbin {\circ } (d_C + \delta _C) \mathbin {\circ } h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h\right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h\right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_\bullet such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}] are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_\bullet are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

Given two chain complexes C, D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to D, a chain map \iota : D \to C and a chain homotopy h : \textrm {id} \to g \mathbin {\circ } f, such that \pi \mathbin {\circ } \iota = \textrm {id}, and \pi \mathbin {\circ } h = h \mathbin {\circ } \iota = h \mathbin {\circ } h = 0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.
We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu}\Rightarrow D. The three components are denoted \pi _{\rho } : C \to D, \iota _{\rho } : D \to C and h_{\rho } : C \to C, respectively.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_\bullet , with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb {Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d\sigma , the generator is called a face of \sigma .
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
